(KKTV) - As more wolves are released as part of reintroduction efforts in Colorado, one expert shared some of the impacts they could have on the people of the state and how officials are trying to facilitate coexistence with the returning species. Colorado Parks and Wildlife announced Friday that five additional wolves had been released in Colorado since the initial release, bringing the total up to 10 as of this article’s last update. Colorado State University’s Center for Human-Carnivore Coexistence Director Kevin Crooks told 11 News he thinks many of the believed effects of wolves’ full reintroduction in the state “tend to be overplayed, they tend to be exaggerated in discourse.” “Colorado is currently a broken link in an otherwise relatively continuous chain of wolf populations along the Rocky Mountains,” Crooks said, adding that a sustainable wolf population in Colorado could close that chain and would be a significant conservation achievement. Despite that, and the support for wolf reintroduction in 2020 that led to their return, it’s still a source of concern for many Coloradans, especially ranchers with livestock in areas wolves will now also live in. “Although most ranchers will not experience direct conflict with wolves here in Colorado, some will and some already have,” Crooks said, “and for those individual ranchers, wolves can have a substantial economic and emotional impact.” Crooks said his team and Colorado Parks and Wildlife have been working on a number of way to address the impacts to individual ranchers, looking into both proactive and reactive responses to situations that could arise with wolves and hosting forums between pro-wolf parties and ranchers for their concerns to be discussed. “These are real impacts that are important to consider,” Crooks said, “important not to minimize, because it’s going to be these individual ranchers that are going to bear the brunt of the cost exerted by wolves.” When it comes to the potential of running across a wolf during a run or hike or visit to a park, Crooks said to enjoy the outdoors and the wildlife, but to stay aware, just like you would with any other potentially threatening wildlife. “Wolves are generally afraid of people, and will avoid them, so they don’t necessarily represent a direct threat to human safety,” Crooks said, “unless people have been habituating them by providing them with food for example.” Crooks’ conversation with 11 News Digital Anchor Lauren Watson, with more information about the work the Center for Human-Carnivore Coexistence is doing and the conversation surrounding wolves in Colorado, can be watched below: Copyright 2023 KKTV.
